    Your outside offer value is 395. Your objective is to maximize your value of the outcome of the negotiation game. Remember, you have a guaranteed alternative: your outside offer.

    The negotiation proceeds in 3 rounds.

Okay, let's start by analyzing the situation. It's round 1, and I'm Player 1. There's no offer on the table. My goal is to maximize my discounted value, taking into account my outside offer of 395 and the discount factor of 0.98.

Since I have no current offer to respond to, I must make an initial offer. To maximize my chances of reaching an agreement, I should offer something reasonable to Player 2, while still securing a good value for myself.  Let's aim for an offer that gives me slightly more than my outside offer, as that gives me room to negotiate.

First, I'll calculate the total value of all items to me:
Item 1: 2 units * 62 = 124
Item 2: 4 units * 98 = 392
Item 3: 3 units * 81 = 243
Item 4: 4 units * 7 = 28
Item 5: 3 units * 13 = 39
Total Value: 124 + 392 + 243 + 28 + 39 = 826

Now, I need to determine a reasonable starting offer. I want to offer Player 2 enough to make it worthwhile for them to accept, but not so much that I get less than my outside offer. Let's try an offer that gives Player 2 roughly half of the total value. A bit less than half would be strategically smart.

Instead of dividing everything in half, let's allocate specific items to Player 2. Since I value item 4 and 5 relatively low, I can give Player 2 all of item 4 and item 5. I also give 1 of item 1, 2 of item 2, and 1 of item 3.
My offer to Player 2: [1, 2, 1, 4, 3]
Value to Player 2: Let's assume their valuations are close to mine.

What I keep:
Item 1: 1 unit * 62 = 62
Item 2: 2 units * 98 = 196
Item 3: 2 units * 81 = 162
Item 4: 0 units * 7 = 0
Item 5: 0 units * 13 = 0
Total value to me: 62 + 196 + 162 + 0 + 0 = 420

This is better than my outside option so seems like a good initial offer.

round_data.response:
Step‐by‐step reasoning:

1. Our “outside” value is 679 (un‐discounted), so by walking we’d get 679. Because we are in Round 2 the agreement payoff is discounted by 0.98 so any deal “raw” value we get will be multiplied by 0.98. In effect we need our “raw” value in a deal to be at least about 679/0.98 ≈ 694 in order for it to beat our fallback.
2. Our private unit values are very skewed: we get 98 and 94 per unit of items 1 and 2 respectively, whereas items 3 (10), 4 (38) and 5 (22) have much lower value for us. Thus our “hot” items are 1 and 2 and we want almost all of them.
3. In earlier rounds Player 1 first offered a deal giving us some of every item, but then in Round 2 they offered [0,0,0,0,0] (i.e. nothing for us). That “extreme” offer shows they are now trying to claim virtually everything for themselves.
4. In our prior counteroffer in Round 1 we effectively claimed all of the high‐valued items for ourselves by offering [0,0,4,1,2] (which gives us items [4,4,0,1,1]). That deal would have given us raw value 4×98+4×94+0×10+1×38+1×22 = 828, more than what we need – but Player 1 did not accept.
5. Now, to get both a deal that nets us above our fallback and also gives Player 1 enough incentive (since if they reject they’d get their private outside offer) we have to “concede” only on the items we care less about. In our case, items 3, 4 and 5 matter much less than items 1 and 2.
6. Therefore a natural counterproposal is to give Player 1 all of the lower‐valuation items (all of items 3, 4 and 5) while keeping all of our “hot” items (items 1 and 2). In numbers that is: offer Player 1: [0,0,4,2,3]. (Note: the “offer” always shows what we give to Player 1; the remainder is our allocation.)

1. First, note that the negotiation is about dividing 5 item types with totals [6, 4, 3, 3, 5]. We each have our own private per‐unit values. My values (as Player 2) are:

 Item 2: 0 × 98 = 0 
 Item 3: 1 × 62 = 62
 Item 4: 1 × 24 = 24
 Item 5: 2 × 1 = 2
 Total = 70 + 0 + 62 + 24 + 2 = 158

3. My outside alternative is 689. Because 158 is much lower than 689, accepting the current offer is clearly not attractive.

4. In a counteroffer I (as Player 2) propose a division by specifying what I give to Player 1. That means if I propose an offer array [n1, n2, n3, n4, n5] then Player 1 will receive those amounts and I will get the leftovers; for each item, my share is (total – offered).

5. To get a final deal that is better than my outside option, I need my own share’s value (without discount in round 1) to exceed 689. My total value if I got all items would be:
 6×70 + 4×98 + 3×62 + 3×24 + 5×1 = 420 + 392 + 186 + 72 + 5 = 1075.
Thus, if I give away items worth no more than 1075 – 689 = 386 (in terms of my own valuations) I ensure a personal payoff above 689.

6. Since I value some items much higher than others, I want to give Player 1 items I care little about while keeping those that are most valuable for me. In my case:
 – Item 5: worth only 1 per unit; conceding these is “cheap” for me.
 – Item 4: worth 24 per unit is not very costly either.
 – Items 1 and 2 are very valuable (70 and 98 respectively).
 – Item 3 (worth 62) is intermediate, but it is the “cheapest” of the high‐valued ones.

7. At the same time, I must offer Player 1 enough so that they prefer the immediate deal (discount factor 1 in round 1) over their uncertain outside offer. Although I cannot know their exact values, given that opponents’ private values are drawn uniformly on [1,101] the expected unit value is roughly 51. Thus, if I “give” about 11 items (in expected value ~ 11×51 = 561) then (on average) Player 1 might see this as competitive with their outside offer.

8. To favor myself, I want to keep items with the highest per‐unit value (items 1 and 2) and offer as a concession types that I value little but which – on expectation – have reasonable worth to Player 1. One natural proposal is to give all of items 3, 4, and 5. But that would mean:
 – For item 3: Giving 3 units costs me 3×62 = 186.
 – For item 4: Giving 3 units costs me 3×24 = 72.
 – For item 5: Giving 5 units costs me 5×1 = 5.
 Total “cost” = 186 + 72 + 5 = 263.
My retained items would then be item 1 (6 units) and item 2 (4 units), for a value of 6×70 + 4×98 = 420 + 392 = 812. While 812 > 689, the expected value to Player 1 would be about 11 items × ~51 per unit = ~561. That might barely beat their outside offer (on average) and given uncertainty, Player 1 might want a bit more.
 
9. To improve Player 1’s position (and incentivize acceptance) while still keeping my total above 689, I can give them one extra unit from an item that I value less relative to typical opponent value. Conceding one unit of item 1 (worth 70 to me) is preferable to conceding one unit of item 3 (worth 62) or item 2 (worth 98) when trying to tip the scales for Player 1. 

10. So consider offering Player 1:
 – Item 1: 1 unit (I keep 5 units)
 – Item 2: 0 units (I keep all 4)
 – Item 3: 3 units (I keep 0)
 – Item 4: 3 units (I keep 0)
 – Item 5: 5 units (I keep 0)
Then my resulting bundle is:
 – Item 1: 5 units → 5×70 = 350
 – Item 2: 4 units → 4×98 = 392
Total = 350 + 392 = 742, which is comfortably above my outside offer of 689.
On the other side, Player 1’s expected benefit (using a rough estimate at 51 per unit if they get roughly their “preferred” types) becomes:
 – Item 1: 1 unit (≈51)
 – Item 3: 3 units (≈153)
 – Item 4: 3 units (≈153)
 – Item 5: 5 units (≈255)
Total ≈ 51 + 153 + 153 + 255 = 612.
This estimated expected value should be competitive with their outside option (especially since they are discounting future rounds).

11. Thus, my counteroffer is to give Player 1

and I keep the remaining items.

 – I present a division that (on expectation) gives Player 1 enough to favor reaching a deal now.

In other words, if I get a deal then I must get nearly every item—losing at most 619–600 = 19 points of value relative to a full allocation—to be as well off as simply walking away.   49 + 36 + 13 + 56 = 154 points,
which is far below my 600‐point outside alternative.

To get a deal that beats 600, I must counteroffer so that I keep at least 600 value for myself. Since my total is 619, I can only “concede” at most 19 value points. And given my private per‐unit values
  item 1: 49, item 2: 36, item 3: 13, item 4: 56, item 5: 36,
the “cheapest” unit (from my perspective) is item 3 (worth 13 to me). (Any other unit would cost me too much, reducing my total below 600.) In fact, if I were to give up one unit of item 3, I’d get 619 – 13 = 606 – which is just above 600. However, offering Player 1 only one unit of item 3 (i.e. a counteroffer of [0,0,1,0,0] which would mean that Player 1 gets that unit and I keep the rest) leaves them with a bundle whose “value to them” is unknown but almost certainly very low relative to what they might secure by walking away with their own outside offer. In other words, it would be extremely unlikely that Player 1’s private outside offer is that low. 

Thus, any deal that allows me to keep my fallback of 600 forces me to concede so little that Player 1 almost certainly will not prefer accepting the deal over their own outside offer.

Given that the current offer is far too low for me and any counteroffer that protects my 600‐point fallback would almost certainly be rejected by Player 1, the best (and rational) action is not to continue bargaining and secure my outside offer.

Step‐by‐step reasoning:
1. We first evaluate the current offer on the table. Player 1’s offer gives us [3, 3, 2, 2, 3] units of items. With our values (item1: 69, item2: 47, item3: 50, item4: 2, item5: 10), that outcome is worth:
  • Item 1: 3×69 = 207
  • Item 2: 3×47 = 141
  • Item 3: 2×50 = 100
  • Item 4: 2×2 = 4
  • Item 5: 3×10 = 30
  Total = 207+141+100+4+30 = 482.
Since we have an outside option of 790, accepting 482 in round 1 is unattractive.

2. As Player 2 we can make a counteroffer by “giving” a certain number of each item type to Player 1; what remains (total minus offered) goes to us. Our goal is to ensure that our share has a value of at least 790. Let the counteroffer be represented by [c1, c2, c3, c4, c5] (the units allocated to Player 1);
  then our share is: [7–c1, 6–c2, 5–c3, 4–c4, 5–c5]
  and its value is:
    69(7–c1) + 47(6–c2) + 50(5–c3) + 2(4–c4) + 10(5–c5).

3. We require that our value is at least 790.
  Since the total maximum value is 1073, giving some items to Player 1 “costs” us an amount equal to:
    69·c1 + 47·c2 + 50·c3 + 2·c4 + 10·c5
and thus we must have:
  1073 – [69·c1 + 47·c2 + 50·c3 + 2·c4 + 10·c5] ≥ 790,
or equivalently,
  69·c1 + 47·c2 + 50·c3 + 2·c4 + 10·c5 ≤ 283.

4. We want to propose a division that gives us above our outside option but also might be palatable to Player 1. Focusing on items we value highly (items 1–3), we try to retain most of those while conceding low‐value items (like item 4) and maybe some of the others. One candidate is:
  – Offer Player 1: 2 units of item 1, 1 unit of item 2, 1 unit of item 3, all 4 units of item 4, and 3 units of item 5.
Let’s check the “cost” to us:
  Cost = 2×69 + 1×47 + 1×50 + 4×2 + 3×10 = 138 + 47 + 50 + 8 + 30 = 273,
which satisfies 273 ≤ 283.
Then our share becomes:
  Item 1: 7–2 = 5 units  → 5×69 = 345
  Item 2: 6–1 = 5 units  → 5×47 = 235
  Item 3: 5–1 = 4 units  → 4×50 = 200
  Item 4: 4–4 = 0 units  → 0×2 = 0
  Item 5: 5–3 = 2 units  → 2×10 = 20
Total value for us = 345 + 235 + 200 + 0 + 20 = 800,
which is above our outside option (790).

5. This counteroffer gives Player 1: [2, 1, 1, 4, 3] (units) and leaves us with the remainder. It is a valid division and improves our position relative to the current offer while ensuring we get 800 in value if accepted.

Based on this analysis, my action is to submit the following counteroffer.

I first note that the current offer gives me only one unit of each item. That amounts to a raw (undiscounted) score for me of

  item1: 1×69 = 69  
  item2: 1×47 = 47  
  item3: 1×50 = 50  
  item4: 1×2  = 2  
  item5: 1×10 = 10  
  Total = 178

After applying the round‑2 discount (0.98¹ = 0.98) its present value is about 174.44. This is very far below my private outside offer value of 790. So accepting is worse than “walking” in my case.

My aim now is to “counteroffer” a division of the items that gives me at least as much (when computed with my private per‐unit values) as my outside option. In other words, I must secure an allocation that “costs” me at most the concession between taking the deal or relying on the outside offer. My total maximum undiscounted value if I got everything would be 1073. Thus I need at least an allocation whose undiscounted worth – when later discounted by 0.98 – comes out to at least 790. In fact, working backward, I’d need at least about 790/0.98 ≈ 806 points in raw value. 

One natural idea is to “keep” almost all of the items with high per‐unit value for me (namely items 1–3: values 69, 47, 50 respectively) and be willing to allow my opponent (Player 1) to have most or all of the items that I value little (in my case, items 4 and 5 where my values are 2 and 10). For example, if I keep an allocation like:

 My share = [6 of item1, 5 of item2, 4 of item3, 0 of item4, 0 of item5]

then my raw value is

 6×69 + 5×47 + 4×50 = 414 + 235 + 200 = 849.

After discounting that becomes 849×0.98 ≈ 832 – comfortably above 790.

Because the totals must add up to the available items, I must assign the remaining units to Player 1. Since there are 7 units of item1, 6 of item2, 5 of item3, 4 of item4, 5 of item5, the complementary (Player 1’s) allocation would be:

 Player 1’s share = [7–6, 6–5, 5–4, 4–0, 5–0] = [1, 1, 1, 4, 5].

This counteroffer not only gives me a payoff above my fallback but also gives Player 1 a “package” (especially in the lower‐value items to me) that they might find attractive relative to their own outside offer. (Without knowing Player 1’s private values, I’m trying to leave them enough so that they prefer agreement to their own alternative.) 

Thus my chosen move is to propose the division in which I keep [6,5,4,0,0] and offer Player 1 [1,1,1,4,5].

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 1, 1, 4, 5]}
